ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course provided incredibly useful historical and legal knowledge about the most important cases of the 20th century.
Really interesting on many great trials of the century.
I learned about the judicial system and also what it takes to go through trials and the difference between cases.

This is the best course I have ever taken at Yale. I learned so much about the most consequential trials in history  the readings, discussions, and assignments help me hone my critical thinking, writing, and reading skills. We got to consider and discuss deep questions that will stay with me for years
This is one of my favorite courses I have ever taken at Yale - Professor Ford is spectacular.
I learned a lot about the legal system and what its like to be a lawyer, which was really interesting and applicable to my potential career plans
How to look at historical facts/court cases objectively and be able to understand the time and context in which they happened, as well as compare this to current standards.

Learned about different trials of the 20th century and their legal and social consequences. Touched on topics of race, gender, and social class, and how they impact our justice system. Learned a lot about the justice system and how it works too. Same with trial procedures.
How to analyze cases from a historical view, connect them to modern times, and compare them to other cases
This class taught me about how legal systems work but more so how the media, culture, and the law can intersect and motivate progress and change.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Prof. Ford was a fantastic teacher, the readings and topics were always engaging, and the final assignment was a fantastic opportunity to dive deep into a case we are passionate about. I have no suggestions.
This course is the best course I have ever taken at Yale.
Amazing class. Only strengths no weaknesses. Professor Ford, the readings, the videos, the discussions, and the assignments were all great.
This class is so engaging - I have never so looked forward to doing reading in my life. Each week was gripping and Professor Ford does an amazing job of explaining the trials and their significance.

This course was amazing! Prof Ford made a 1hr50 seminar feel like 30 mins. Hes a really engaging lecturer and the content we covered was interesting. It wouldve been nice to have more time for student discussions and also to have a better idea of how students are doing grade-wise earlier in the semester
Professor Ford made it comfortable for everyone to share thoughts and was a very engaging speaker.

No weaknesses. Strengths: I absolutely loved this course, and it was my favorite one I've ever taken at Yale. Professor Ford's knowledge and enthusiasm make for a wonderful classroom environment that will be memorable after you graduate.
such an amazing interesting course. Favourite class I have taken at Yale.
No weaknesses. It's an extremely interesting class with a low workload

The class has a lot of great resources and the readings/videos are informative and fun to go through. One issue with the class is it didnt feel as much like a seminar as I would have hoped, so if youre looking for that then maybe this isnt the best option. That said, I did learn a lot and was able to get a better understanding of history through the law.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES best class at Yale

Absolutely. Prof. Ford is not only a major figure in law and media but an incredible instructor. He took us through incredibly complex cases in engaging ways, led powerful discussions, and was always willing to spend extra time with students on papers/topics/etc.
Absolutely. Professor ford is the best professor Ive had and the class is incredibly interesting. The professor is engaging and values students opinions.
ABSOLUTELY! Everyone should take this class Best class at Yale. Professor Ford is amazing.
One of the best classes I have taken ever.
Absolutely. Best class I have taken at Yale.
Yes!

Yes, I think it's important to learn about our legal system and court system and how it has evolved over the years. Also the course felt very low-stakes and not too intense like some seminars I have taken.

I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone looking to take a class at Yale that feels different from other seminars you've taken. Unlike other classes I've taken, this seminar genuinely felt discussion-based, and I left every class feeling like I learned something new. This class is one where students can guide the conversation however they please, and don't get too bogged down in what the readings specifically say. The readings are super interesting because they are trial summaries, trial transcripts, and documentaries/movies  I found myself watching the latter with my family and friends because it was THAT interesting. Professor Ford is an incredible teacher and mentor, and you will forever be grateful you took this class with him.
Yes!! if you get the chance, take this class.
Yes, this is the best class I have taken at Yale. It is different from anything I have taken and is so interesting
Yes! Professor Ford is SO COOL and hearing about his life is definitely worth it. He also takes students to lunch which is very fun and is overall a great professor to have.

By far the best course that I have taken at Yale. Professor Ford is not only a great professor but an unbelievably great person--the passion that he has on the submit translates into the classroom and is reflected by the class' regular engagement. I cannot think of a moment when the class was silent, as we were constantly on top of the material. I can say with full honesty that this is the first (and last) class at Yale where I completed all of the assigned readings and work. I am fortunate to have had the opportunity to take this course during my four years.
